subject: RE: [junit] random testing with JUnit
msgSnippet: ... If you use random seeds and that the seed used is part of the report, it s actually possible to recreate the exact same series of random numbers that led
messageBody:
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of Elliotte Harold

> This strikes me as a very bad idea. If you get the code to
> break, how are you going to repeat it? And then how are you
> going to know if you've fixed the bug?

If you use random seeds and that the seed used is part of the report, it's
actually possible to recreate the exact same series of random numbers that
led to the crash.

Besides, while the input might be random, the test will fail for a
particular value, which can be included in the report.

> Much better to throw *every* possibility at the code, rather
> than just a random selection.

That's definitely a worthwhile solution as well, but it's not always
applicable, depending on the range of values your tests can accept...

> Random generation of test data is antithetical to test driven development.


I disagree. A lot of programs work based on random generations, so it
should come as no surprise that tests can do that as well, as long as the
failure can be reproduced when it occurs.
